Method Detail

formatCurrency

public String formatCurrency(long amount,
                             String currencyCode,
                             boolean international,
                             boolean showGroupings)
Description copied from interface: LocalizedParser
Convert a fixed-point currency amount into a string. If international is true, the international currency symbol will be used; e.g. $5.25 becomes C$5.25 or US$5.25 depending on the currency. This allows currency values to be distinguished among countries using the same currency symbol. The fixed-point representation of the currency value is the number of the smallest denomination of currency; e.g. the number of cents. The parser will have to know how many subdivisions there are to a single unit. For CAD, USD, and EUR (as well as many other currencies) there are two decimal places, meaning the number is divided by 100 and shown with 2 decimal places. Other currencies have no subdivisions (INR for example) and can be formatted with no decimal places and do not have to be divided by anything.

Specified by:
formatCurrency in interface LocalizedParser
showGroupings - TODO

public String formatDate(Date date,
                         boolean shortFormat)
Description copied from interface: LocalizedParser
Format a date using a standard output format, based on the locale of this parser.

Specified by:
formatDate in interface LocalizedParser
shortFormat - If true, use a short format like 12/5/2007 instead of Dec 5, 2007
Returns:
A string for that date

formatDecimal

public String formatDecimal(double val,
                            boolean groupings)
Description copied from interface: LocalizedParser
Format a double number. If showGroupings is true, locale-specific seperators will be added to the string, e.g. 1,234,567.89 in most places, or 1.234.567,89 in European locales.

Specified by:
formatDecimal in interface LocalizedParser

formatPercentage

public String formatPercentage(double value)
Description copied from interface: LocalizedParser
Format a percentage. Typically this means adding "%" to end and formatting as a decimal number. This should round to a reasonable number of decimal places, and ideally strip off any trailing zeroes and even the decimal point if possible. The algorithm should keep up to 4 decimal places, but should strip any trailings zeroes and remove the decimal seperator it it is unnecessary.

Specified by:
formatPercentage in interface LocalizedParser

parseCurrency

public long parseCurrency(String currencyString,
                          String currencyCode)
                   throws CurrencyParseException,
                          DifferentCurrencyCodeProvided
Description copied from interface: LocalizedParser
Parse a currency value. The currencyString may optionally start or end with currency-specific suffix and prefix as support by this parser. The input may be using the international or non-international currency code; the parser should allow both, if it is capable of outputting the international code.

Specified by:
parseCurrency in interface LocalizedParser
Throws:
DifferentCurrencyCodeProvided - If the algorithm is smart enough to detect that the currency string given is indicating a different currency than the one given, it'll throw this exception and you can do with it as you please (you might use it to adjust the currency selection in the UI automatically).
CurrencyParseException

parseDate

public Date parseDate(String dateString)
               throws DateParseException
Description copied from interface: LocalizedParser
Parse a date in as flexible a format as possible using the locale of this parser. On the client side, this is typically implemented using DateJs.

Specified by:
parseDate in interface LocalizedParser
Throws:
DateParseException - If the date could not be recognized by the parser

parsePercentage

public double parsePercentage(String val)
                       throws NumberFormatException
Description copied from interface: LocalizedParser
Parse a percentage; any "%" suffix should be stripped and the number divided by 100.0. Like parseDecimal this should honor the locale-specific separators if they are present.

Specified by:
parsePercentage in interface LocalizedParser
Throws:
NumberFormatException
